Yes.Title: Are you comparing more than 2 groups?
Kruskal Wallis Test
Yes.Description: It is a test used to compare 3 or more independent groups, their measures must be numerical and non-parametric. It´s parametric counterpart is the One-Factor ANOVA.

No.Title: U-Mann Whitney Test
No.Description: It is a test used to compare 2 groups with different measures and analyze if it´s averages are significantly different between each other. It must be used ins nonparametric numerical Variables. It´s parametric counterpart is the T-student test.

No.Title: Are you comparing more than 2 mesures?

Yes.Title: Friedman Test
Yes.Description: It is a test used to compare 1 group, with 3 or more measures that must be numerical and non-parametric. It´s parametric test is the Repeated measured

No.Title: Wilcoxon Test
No.Description: It is a test used when you compare the measures of the same group 2 times and its measures are parametric, continous variables. It´s parametric counterpart is the T-test paired dependent groups.

Yes.Title: Spearman correlation Test
Yes.Description: It is a test that measures the statistical relationship, or association between 2 nonparametric variables. It does not explains cause and effect, only the amount of association existing between the 2 variables. It´s parametric counterpart is the Pearson correlation.

No.Title: Intraclass correlation coefficient Test
No.Description: The intraclass correlation coefficient is a reliability index in test, re-test, intrarater, and interrater reliability analyses. Used when it is intended to observe the degree of agreement between measures. It must be used with continous variables.

Yes.Title: Are you comparing more than 2 groups?
One-Factor ANOVA Test
Yes.Description: It is a test used to compare 3 or more independent groups, their measures must be continous and parametric. It´s non parametric counterpart is the Kruskall-Wallis Test.

No.Title: T student (Independent groups)
No.Description: It is a test used to compare 2 groups with different measures and analyze if it´s averages are significantly different between each other. It must be used in continous parametric Variables. It´s non-parametric counterpart is the U-Mann Whitney test.

No.Title: Are you comparing more than 2 mesures?

Yes.Title: Repeated measures ANOVA Test
Yes.Description: It is a test used to compare 1 group, with 3 or more measures that must be continous and parametric. It´s non parametric test is the Friedman Test.

No.Title: T student (Dependent groups) Test
No.Description: It is a test used when you compare the measures of the same group 2 times and its measures are parametric continous variables. It´s non parametric counterpart is the Wilcoxon-ranked Test.

Yes.Title: Pearson correlation Test
Yes.Description: The pearson correlation coefficient is a test that measures the statistical relationship, or association between 2 parametric variables. It does not explains cause and effect, only the amount of association existing between the 2 variables. It´s non parametric counterpart is Spearman correlation.

No.Title: Coefficient correlation intraclass (Seeking concordance) Test
No.Description: The intraclass correlation coefficient is a reliability index in test, re-test, intrarater, and interrater reliability analyses. Used when it is intended to observe the degree of agreement between measures. It must be used with continous variables.

No.Title: Do you want to analyze numeric and categoric variables?

Yes.Title: Spearman correlation
Yes.Description: The spearman correlation coefficient is a test that measures the statistical relationship, or association between 2 nonparametric variables. It does not explains cause and effect, only the amount of association existing between the 2 variables. It´s parametric counterpart is the Pearson correlation.

Yes.Title: Are you comparing more than 2 groups?
Fisher's Test or Chi squared Test
Yes.Description: It is a test used to compare proportions or percentages (qualitative variables) between 2 groups. When you perform a contingency table with 2 columns and 2 rows it is adequate to select the p value in the Fisher Test row. The Fisher´s exact Test is a statistical significance test that can calculate the significance of the deviation of the null hypothesis exactly, rather than relying on approximation.

No.Title: Chi squared Test
No.Description: It is a test used to compare proportions or percentages (qualitative variables) between 2 groups.

No.Title: Are you comparing more than 2 groups?

Yes.Title: Cochran Q Test
Yes.Description: Is an extension of the McNemar Test, for related samples that provides a method for testing differences between 3 or more matched sets of frequencies or proportions.

No.Title: McNemar Test
No.Description: Is a statistical test used on paired nominal data applied to 2 x 2 contingency tables with dichotomous variables for matched pairs of subjects to determine if the frequencies are equal.

Yes.Title: Fleiss Kappa
Yes.Description: Fleiss Kappa is a statistical measure for assessing the reliability of agreement between a fixed number of raters (comparing 3 or more raters). It is recommended when you have a Likert Scale, ordinal data, or nominal data(categorical variables).

No.Title: Cohen´s Kappa, or Weighted Kappa
No.Description: Kappa is a test to compare two qualitative methods (two raters only), a test method against a reference / comparative method to determine accuracy. It can be called Kappa test for inter-rater agreement. A weighted variation is used when you have ordinal answers (example: low, medium, high). It´s numerical quantitative counterpart is the Intraclass correlation coefficient.
